97f98e5df342.description: Perspectives of a 2x entrepreneur turned VC at @UpfrontVC, the largest and most active early-stage fund in Southern California. Snapchat: msuster
97f98e5df342.name: Both Sides of the Table
97f98e5df342.shortDescription: Perspectives of a 2x entrepreneur turned VC at @UpfrontVC…

paragraphs.text: I find over-introducers are often motivated by their own self currency. Showing founders they know important people makes them feel more self important. They assume that helping senior executives meet interesting startup people will show the introduced party that they are tapped in and relevant.

paragraphs.name: a1af
paragraphs.text: Over introducers use this currency liberally because in the absence of any real operating knowledge or without actually taking the time to diagnose what the important issues are at a company and how to truly be helpful, over-introducers fall back on the easiest and often least-productive form of help.

Over introducers use this currency liberally because in the absence of any real operating knowledge or without actually taking the time to diagnose what the important issues are at a company and how to truly be helpful, over-introducers fall back on the easiest and often least-productive form of help.
paragraphs.name: a1af
a5f5
paragraphs.text: That’s why focus is critical. Saying “no” often to people who want to divert you from your mission becomes obligatory if you want to make progress. Modern-society is also littered with over-networkers and over-introducers and professional conference attendees. These people are like the friend in college who always tempted you by telling you about the latest party when you were at the library studying.

I know some will read this as an indictment of all introductions and of course it’s not that. I introduce people constantly and it’s an important part of my job. Each time I carefully consider whether the connection would be helpful to each party and I almost always ask both sides whether it’s ok.
paragraphs.name: 0e69

paragraphs.text: Mostly I just wanted to write this as a reminder to founders to be suspicious of people who constantly introduce you around. And maybe also a reminder that the library, while infinitely less exciting than the party, is where real breakthroughs occur.
paragraphs.name: d708

paragraphs.text: Very true. Introductions can be “signal” or “noise”. Founders definitely should curate those intros and be willing to say NO when appropriate, but I think the earlier step for the founder is to establish their own networking goals. They need to specify what kind of connections they are looking for and then communicate it clearly to those who can help…
paragraphs.name: 7dd9

virtuals.subtitle: As regards double-opt-in intros, my startup actually streamlined that process considerably as just one of the features of the LincSphere…

content.subtitle: As regards double-opt-in intros, my startup actually streamlined that process considerably as just one of the features of the LincSphere…

paragraphs.text: The Art of a Graceful Introduction; the Why, Method & Mechanics.

content.subtitle: The Art of a Graceful Introduction; the Why, Method & Mechanics.

7c9163b39be6.title: It’s a hard one, for sure.

paragraphs.text: It’s a hard one, for sure. Of course intros help and I do many. Equally many people are over introducers. So it’s a balance. We discuss this a lot internally — about finding the right balance. Default internal — if you intro be sure it’s necessary and not just helping you to feel useful.
paragraphs.name: d9af

paragraphs.text: Quality > quantity
paragraphs.name: 7b9f

paragraphs.text: Very interesting Mark. Appreciate your writing this. As an Associate in VC I often find myself offering introductions to founders — not exactly in lieu of providing operational experience/advice, but perhaps unconsciously I am. Many thank yous come my way from intros I’ve made, but then again, who knows how many intros aren’t adding value. Will keep this in mind as I go forward…
paragraphs.name: e97c

6ed1e6674602.title: Knowing what to do is just as important as knowing what not to do.

paragraphs.text: Knowing what to do is just as important as knowing what not to do. I think, learning how to say NO is one of the most important tools to a life of abundance. When Steve Jobs returned to Apple after Next, one of the first things he did was cut the product range by 70%, and it worked out pretty well didn’t it?
paragraphs.name: 3e09

virtuals.subtitle: We can’t do it all at once, and in my opinion it’s much better to focus down on the top priorities being all over the place. I’m glad that…

16c1d3c2ff9.title: A close relative is the “name dropper”.

paragraphs.text: A close relative is the “name dropper”. This person always asks do you know so and so, in some very tangential way to the topic being discussed.
paragraphs.name: 2ce4

paragraphs.text: They don’t really have a close relationship with so and so and the value of the meeting is vague.
paragraphs.name: 41c0

paragraphs.text: Maybe not as bad because you aren’t going to get the meeting, but still a major distraction.
paragraphs.name: de08

virtuals.subtitle: They don’t really have a close relationship with so and so and the value of the meeting is vague.

content.subtitle: They don’t really have a close relationship with so and so and the value of the meeting is vague.

paragraphs.text: Good reminder Mark. I’ve been the victim of this and it’s a slippery slope. If the person introducing you is a solid connection you don’t want to miss a potentially beneficial introduction or run the risk of offending them but there is only so much time and attention one can dedicate to connecting.
paragraphs.name: 604d

virtuals.subtitle: I am a big believer in open communication and guiding how and when to have someone introduce me. If the person says I have 3–5 people they…

c3b6c2b2f02d.title: Mark — I don’t read this as an indictment of all introductions, but I think you must have had a…

paragraphs.text: Mark — I don’t read this as an indictment of all introductions, but I think you must have had a particularly annoying experience with an introducer to write this pissed off message. This seems to me a rather trivial part of the larger problem facing busy people of deciding what meetings are worth their time.

fa084cfe79c2.title: Introducing people to each other in an elegant and pertinent way is an art.

paragraphs.text:
Introducing people to each other in an elegant and pertinent way is an art. And a job.
Like for public speaking, the problem is that the myth of “anybody can do it at least at an average level” is strong.
This is the TEDx-isation of the art of introducing.

dc5361b7600b.title: Agreed whole heartedly with you on this.

paragraphs.text: Agreed whole heartedly with you on this. Knowing someone well enough to introduce them to another business associate to me means you are vouching to the two parties that they are 100% reliable and trustworthy which to me means someone I’ve done business with for several years and not simply someone I’ve chatted with a few times at a Meetup event.
paragraphs.name: e281

af95583d1800.title: A highly valuable perspective, Mark, Thanks for sharing.

paragraphs.text: A highly valuable perspective, Mark, Thanks for sharing. To mirror Joshua Baer’s sentiments, I am definitely at risk of being an over-introducer. However, I agree with Brad Feld. I would also submit that its the accuracy of a situational-value assessment, vetted heritage (VC/Angel/Private Equity, startup advisory and/or professional domain expertise…
